patterns: What are epilepsy symptoms?
How do I know if someone has epilepsy?
What are the signs of a seizure?
responses: Common epilepsy symptoms include temporary confusion, staring spells, uncontrollable jerking movements, loss of consciousness, and cognitive/emotional changes. Symptoms vary depending on seizure type.

patterns: What should I do if someone has a seizure?
How can I help during a seizure?
What are first aid steps for epilepsy?
responses: Key steps: 1) Stay calm 2) Clear area of hazards 3) Cushion head 4) Time seizure 5) Turn person on side 6) Stay with them 7) Call emergency services if >5 minutes or breathing difficulties

patterns: How is epilepsy treated?
What are the treatment options for epilepsy?
Can epilepsy be cured?
responses: Primary treatments: Anti-seizure medications (ASMs), dietary therapy (ketogenic/Modified Atkins), surgery (resection/disconnection), neurostimulation devices (VNS/RNS/DBS), and lifestyle modifications.

patterns: What triggers a seizure?
Can stress cause epilepsy?
What should epilepsy patients avoid?
responses: Common triggers: Sleep deprivation (most common), stress, alcohol/drug use, flashing lights (photosensitive epilepsy), menstrual cycle changes, missed medications, and illness/fever.

patterns: What diet is good for epilepsy?
Can food affect seizures?
Is keto diet helpful for epilepsy?
responses: Medically supervised ketogenic diet (high fat, low carb) helps control seizures in 30-40% of pediatric cases. Modified Atkins and low glycemic index diets are alternatives for adults.

patterns: What are common epilepsy medications?
Do I have to take epilepsy medicine forever?
Can missing a dose trigger a seizure?
responses: Common ASMs: Levetiracetam, Lamotrigine, Valproate, Carbamazepine. Medication duration depends on seizure control - some may require lifelong treatment. Never stop medication without medical supervision.

What to do if a seizure doesnâ€™t stop?
How long is too long for a seizure?
responses: Seek immediate medical help if: First seizure, >5 minutes duration, repeated seizures, breathing difficulties, injury occurs, or occurs in water. Status epilepticus is a medical emergency.

patterns: Is epilepsy contagious?
Can you swallow your tongue during a seizure?
Are flashing lights the only trigger?
responses: Myth busters: Epilepsy isn't contagious. Physically impossible to swallow your tongue. Only 3-5% have photosensitive epilepsy. People with epilepsy can have normal intelligence and productive lives.
